If we start elementary schools at 8:00, and middle school and high school at 9:00, we have to run all the busses twice, and that is too expensive. If we move the elementary schools to 9:00 as well, then parents have to find child care for before school as well as after. If we move schools to 10:30-5:30 to solve that, so they only need before school care, then there isn't enough time (and daylight in winter) for after school activities. There is no perfect solution, so the schools choose the path of least resistance and go with no solution.

Trigger warning for this next paragraph

End of trigger warning

I find the argument of some biological or evolutionary reason for differing sleep rhythms in adolescents weak, considering what we know about sleep cycles before electricity: it is widely known that people in the middle ages went to sleep as early as 6pm due to the simple fact that there was little to no opportunity to work or play without natural light. This would apply to children, adolescents and adults alike. How is it then argued that a difference in sleep cycle is due to inherent traits in differently aged humans, rather than an effect of social and cognitive differences (such as younger people having less willpower to stick to a proper sleep schedule, for example)? Surely, this is not an effect of ~600 years of evolution!

I'm all for creating solutions that allow students to be at their best in school with a full night's sleep, but I don't see how pushing the schedules forward could be a permanent solution to this problem. What sucks about school is how much the negative qualities of the system affect everything about a teen's life. It's not just how early school starts, it's how much work students are pressured into taking on. Especially in high school, the perception shared to students is to constantly be working and doing difficult classes in order to get into a good college and be successful, which only increases how many hours we need in a day. Plus, the way grades are set up in America, a student's performance in a class is measured less on personal self-growth and more about constantly regurgitating information and never messing up. A student who starts a class not knowing anything, but learns the most about the topic, most likely would have a grade around the C to B range, since they would have to make lots of mistakes to actually learn. On the other hand, a hypothetical student who knows everything and never messes up would get a perfect 100 percent at the end of the year. Both of these factors combine to create an environment in which students are put into a never-ending rat race, and are forced to stay up late, as they feel like they never have the time to finish their work otherwise. I can speak from personal experience, as I am currently in high school, that it feels like there is never enough time. No one gets enough sleep. Everyone is so tired and overworked. I talked to one of my peers, and they told me that school feels so suffocating, like you can't breathe. They told me that it feels like you're never able to take a break or go to sleep because, in order to be successful, you have to do everything at once. The issue here is that the majority of people who want to make these kinds of schedule changes are, of course, the students. Bowing to the wishes of the students can be a very slippery slope (give an inch, take a mile sort of thing) so schools are not quick to make sweeping changes solely based on student advocacy. What's needed is more informed adult representation on behalf of the students. Particularly within the school boards since teachers themselves don't have very much administrative power in most states. However, this requires parents and other adults to take a considerable interest in developmental psychology which is not always at the forefront of their minds especially when they recall how hardcore school was for them when they were students. Maybe I'm making some leaps in logic here, but as a teacher, these are some of the things that I see regarding the issue.

As an aside, you can also make the conclusion that smarter and more academically proficient students are managing their time, able to finish their work, and giving school the attention it's asking for. It's not intrinsically related to who gets more or less sleep in my opinion.

I'm pretty confident I've been hit really hard with this effect of school:
(WARNING: THIS IS LONG. Basically, I've had some very noticeable symptoms of some sort of cognitive decline over the course of high school)

When I went into Highschool, I was super smart (according to lots of other people, not myself). Not bragging, just stating it how it was, and the other students in my freshman class quickly started identifying me as one of the really smart kids once it started showing. I was quick-minded, mentally very awake, full of energy, I was a fast learner and good at following directions easily and quickly, I was knowledgeable and could explain most of the stuff in class (as well as plenty of other things we weren't studying) in detail before we had even learned much of it, especially with history, I became known for practically helping teach the class because I could always give in-depth answers from the start and already knew so much, I was a complete math nerd, a level ahead of my grade, and could do fairly advanced math completely in my head and fast, had a very good sense of math and numbers and was even somewhat knowledgeable on quantum mechanics and could mostly understand books talking about it, my memory was really good and was something I became known for especially concerning memorization, my sense of musical rhythm was really good and I often became the orchestra's counter of sorts, I was a good writer, and...well you get the point. Names people gave to me included words like "prodigy, genius, Renaissance Man, intellectual, etc." My oh my, how poorly those titles have aged:

NOW, I graduated high school, and I'm kind of a bit of an idiot. I literally feel like I've experienced some degree of cognitive decline. Senior-year and present-day me has literally nothing on middle school to early high school me aside from maybe knowing some additional facts younger me hadn't been told yet. Back then there were many calling me a kind of genius/prodigy of sorts (an exaggeration in my opinion but okay cool) but now I'm like the farthest thing from that, I feel more below-average now than anything. I need to hear things or read things MULTIPLE times over before I even begin to comprehend it, meaning I also learn slow and need to hear directions more than once oftentimes before I can reliably follow them, I've forgotten at least half of the vast knowledge I used to have 4 years ago (I can only give you super general statements about historical events, whereas before I could like narrate the entire story of Atilla the Hun or the fall of the Byzantine empire or Otto Von Bismarck or whatever in great detail on the spot with ease), my mind is so much slower at nearly everything, my memory isn't nearly as good, and while I'm still I guess slightly above average at memorization it takes more effort now, my sense of rhythm is no longer basically an internal metronome and it's really nothing above average anymore, and my math ability has perhaps had some of the worst hits: For most of my life up into high school I was known as THE math kid, I loved math, was ahead in math, could do it quickly with ease, but now I can't do nearly as much math mentally as easily, it takes way longer to do so now, doing math in GENERAL takes me much much longer, I don't even have freaking times tables or even ADDITION tables down anymore and have to keep double and triple checking to myself what 6 x 4 or 8 + 3 is or whatever, and it's gotten so bad that I now need time and a half on math-related tests when before I was the type who would finish early and would have done most of the test in my head (and still getting correct answers) if I wasn't required to "show my work."

Not only that, but it's impacted my interactions with people. I ended high school with a lot of genuine friends but I'm pretty sure that's thanks to the fact that I made most of those friendships and became well known in the first couple years of high school, when I had rather strong cognitive abilities and whatnot, and so I still have those friends and can talk with them now despite the apparent decline, not because I'm still good at interactions and making friends but because I had already made them. Because NOW in college I still haven't really made ANY new friends or anything, I can't keep a conversation up for the life of me, but I also don't want to talk to people anymore. Not only that, but I've noticed a startling decline in any ROMANTIC interest or anything. In middle school and high school it was pretty typical for someone that age, I felt a very strong attraction to girls (I'm straight) and had pretty healthy typical romantic desire. But in the past year I've noticed that increasingly drop off a cliff; people say college is a good time to start dating but I now have practically ZERO romantic desire whatsoever, I've turned almost asexual for no apparent reason, I feel no attraction to or interest in ANYONE at all.

I'm pretty certain this decline in my abilities is largely due to the problems with school and that it's slowly been killing my brain. I started to notice this apparent decline in sophomore year of high school, but even then it was nowhere near as bad as now, I was still pretty good at the stuff I used to be good at and I still had normal romantic interests for a teenager. But I had to pull a whopping 5 all-nighters in 10th grade, and like 2 in 11th, and then a lot late nights in both years plus senior year, and school started before 8:15 in the morning, and I have no doubt those were massive hits to my brain and cognitive ability.

I was one of the smart kids going into high school, but now I feel below-average (then again if most kids are getting hit by the effects of this, I guess the average has lowered too but still). The only things I've really retained are memorization ability, most of my musical skill, my hand-eye coordination to an extent, my physical drawing skill, but I've lost almost all my motivation to actually do any art projects so I rarely use it, my writing quality (though it takes forever for me to actually write something that's not a stupidly long YouTube comment no one's going to read lol), my vocabulary, and apparently my SAT score (I somehow managed to get a 1560, but that was with an extra time accommodation so even that was still harmed), and maybe a couple other things. But my retention is pretty bad, and all the other things I mentioned before. I've definitely experienced some degree of cognitive decline over the course of high school, to the point where I'm way less cognitively able than I was 4 years ago, and yet I'm still young, what SHOULD be still too young to be worrying about cognitive decline or anything.

Incidentally (or not), I'm bipolar too, and my symptoms worsened right after leaving HS (though diagnosis was still a good 5 years away). If my school days started at 9, I'd still struggle for first period, but that alone would still be a reduction of over 60% on the time I spent sleeping in class and, knowing that I'm a pretty extreme case, that'd probably solve the entire issue for most of other in-class sleeping peers. Plus, that'd probably give me the ability to have a decent breakfast and benefit from some much needed glucose in my brain at schooltime and maybe be able to stay up for that first class - it's kinda hard to eat when you're still groggy from sleep and your stomach still seems to be in dreamland.
